item.title: Confusion Remains as Voting Begins in Greek Referendum
item.description: The results of the referendum could reshape their nation’s place in Europe, but for many Greeks, it was hard to know exactly what they were voting for.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: Confusion Remains as Voting Begins in Greek Referendum
item.description: The results of the referendum could reshape their nation’s place in Europe, but for many Greeks, it was hard to know exactly what they were voting for.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: Day of Reckoning for Greek Banks and Eurozone’s Central Banker
item.description: Unless the European Central Bank decides Greece’s banks deserve further support, they will probably collapse, taking the nation’s economy with them.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A woman cast her vote at a polling station in Athens on Sunday.

item.title: Argentine Judges Allowed to Resign After Child Abuse Ruling
item.description: The two judges had cut a convicted child abuser’s sentence in half because they claimed the 6-year-old victim had displayed homosexual tendencies.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: Murder Complaints Filed Against Ferry Crew in Philippines
item.description: The police in a central Philippine city filed murder complaints against the owner and the crew of a ferry that capsized, leaving more than 50 people dead.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Soldiers Used ‘Restraint’ in Kabul Confrontation, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The investigation examined a violent confrontation between Afghan residents and United States soldiers after a Taliban bomb ripped through a heavily armored convoy of troops in Kabul.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Dominican Plan to Expel Haitians Tests Close Ties
item.description: Many in the Dominican Republic favor being part of a trend of tightening immigration. But for some, it means facing some difficult choices.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and SANDRA E. GARCIA
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yibel Solimo shows the ID he was given as a temporary worker in the Dominican Republic’s cane fields. He hopes it will spare him from deportation.

item.title: State of Emergency Is Declared in Tunisia
item.description: A week after a terrorist attack killed more than 30 foreign tourists, President Beji Caid Essebsi of Tunisia has declared a state of emergency that will increase the powers of the security services.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Militants and Soldier Are Killed in Kashmir Gun Battle, Indian Official Says
item.description: At least two people suspected of being militants and one soldier were killed near the disputed border with Pakistan, an Indian Army official said.
item.dc:creator: SAMEER YASIR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Bailout Referendum Lays Bare Deep Schisms Among Beleaguered Greeks
item.description: While nobody knows what the vote’s outcome will bring, one thing is certain: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras’s gambit has deepened rifts.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alexis Giannopoulis, a butcher, carries a pistol and wads of cash to pay his suppliers. He says he will vote to approve the European bailout in Sunday’s referendum.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Visit to Latin America Will Test His Ability to Keep Catholics in the Fold
item.description: The pontiff’s roots in Argentina and his championing of the poor are considered vital to stemming the decline of the church’s vast base in the region.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: Images of Pope Francis for sale in Caacupé, in Paraguay.

item.title: Paris’s Voiceless Find a Megaphone Online
item.description: Self-described citizen journalism, the Bondy Blog provides a platform to those in the city’s impoverished suburbs, regularly reporting on politics and social issues of the area.
item.dc:creator: AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Faiza Zerouala, left, and Widad Ketfi are journalists with the Bondy Blog, which focuses on politics and social issues around Paris.

item.title: U.N. Nuclear Chief Is Optimistic About Iranian Cooperation on Review
item.description: Completing an assessment on Iran’s suspected past nuclear work by December might help speed up lifting of sanctions, and remove a major hurdle in the talks.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Mohammad Javad Zarif, Iran’s foreign minister, during a meeting with Secretary of State John Kerry as part of nuclear negotiations in Vienna on Friday.

item.title: China Moves to Stabilize Stock Markets; Initial Offerings Halted
item.description: The country’s biggest brokerage firms unveiled a government-backed plan to buy shares, while its stock exchanges suspended all further initial public offerings of stock.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Syria Forces and Hezbollah Attack Insurgents Near Lebanon
item.description: Government forces and their allies in the Lebanese Shiite group began an offensive in Zabadani, a mountain town.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Afghan Forces Battle Taliban as Lawmakers Reject Defense Minister
item.description: Casualties from the battle in Wardak Province were said to be high, and senior officials criticized security forces’ response as slow and ineffective.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: French Honors for an American Veteran of the ‘Monuments Men’
item.description: Harry L. Ettlinger rescued a Rembrandt self-portrait in World War II. On Friday, he was among more than 20 veterans honored in Manhattan by French officials.
item.dc:creator: ILEANA NAJARRO
item.media:description: Jean-Yves Le Drian, the French defense minister, embraced a newly decorated veteran at a ceremony honoring World War II service members at South Street Seaport in Manhattan on Friday.

item.title: Survivor of ’05 London Subway Attack Is on Antiterror Mission
item.description: Gill Hicks, who lost her legs in a bombing and now runs a counterextremism group, says people must learn empathy with terrorists to learn how to defeat them.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Maja Daniels for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gill Hicks on Tuesday in London at the King’s Cross subway stop where she was wounded 10 years ago in a bombing.

item.title: An American Tip to German Spies Points to a More Complex Relationship
item.description: The Obama administration risked exposing its surveillance out of concern over a perceived security breach, leading to an official’s demotion and to widespread German anger.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE, MELISSA EDDY, DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Surrogate Children Win Legal Recognition
item.description: France’s highest court, the Court of Cassation, on Friday granted legal recognition to surrogate children, in a major turnaround that will make their daily lives easier.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
